newsitem.title: USA: Internet startup company takes aim at bottlenecks.
newsitem.headline: Internet startup company takes aim at bottlenecks.

text.p: A small Silicon Valley startup company believes it has an answer to help Internet users fed up with the World Wide Wait.

VitalSigns Software Inc., a company founded by networking industry executives, plans Monday to launch a "browser companion" that will let Web surfers diagnose where slowdowns are occurring in the World Wide Web.

"This will literally help you improve your network performance," VitalSigns CEO Montgomery Kersten said of the company's Net.Medic software product, which will be available Monday for a free 30-day trial period.
The software will sell for around $50 for a personal license, or $10 less in an initial promotion.

The product provides a dashboard-like interface that enables users to monitor the health and performance of their computers, modems and Internet service provider to figure out exactly where delays are occurring.
Kersten said that by helping individual Internet users identify where problems lie, the company hopes to encourage suppliers to improve their service performance.
It plans to launch products for companies running Internet software and for Internet service providers themselves during the summer, hoping better measurement and diagnosis will improve service.

VitalSigns said it expects performance can be boosted by 50 percent using its products, while putting the heat on poor performers by using its software as what it calls a "Darwinian accelerator" by helping the best to succeed.
"We're trying to bring a fact-based relationship and a modern consumer relationship to this thing called the Internet," said Kersten.
VitalSigns currently has a direct sales force of four and is seeking to build sales through equipment makers and third parties, such as networking and modem companies.
The company, founded last year, last week raised a little more than $5.5 million in venture investment backed by Sequoia Capital Partners, LLC, and Austin Ventures.
Its directors includes executives and technologists of Netscape Communications Corp., Microsoft Corp. and Bay Networks. Three of its executives came from Bay Networks.
Santa Clara-based company's software will compete against diagnostic and management products from a variety of vendors, including computer giant Hewlett-Packard Co..

Kerstin said Net.Medic is designed to work with a wide range of products, and that VitalSigns has received interest from computer makers as well as others, possibly to bundle Net.Medic with their products.
Net.Medic runs on Microsoft's Windows 95, Windows NT 4.0, Netscape Communications' Netscape Navigator 3.0 or later and Microsoft IE 3.0 or later.
